content.webTitle: Charges to cover poll may breach cash rules

fields.headline: Charges to cover poll may breach cash rules
fields.bodyText: Newspaper and TV companies covering the top three political leaders during the forthcoming general election may have to be classed as party donors because of the level of charges being levied by the parties to accompany Tony Blair, William Hague, and Charles Kennedy on buses and planes. The Tories want £9,000 per journalist for the three week campaign, Labour £8,750, and the Liberal Democrats are charging £5,000; the latter are also charging £500 for a day with Mr Kennedy. The parties defend the charges as being "as much as the market will bear". They also say that it it is expensive to organise the trips, involving hiring planes and helicopters. The electoral commission, a new body that will supervise the funding and conduct of elections and referendums, is likely to press for a breakdown of the tour costs. Otherwise it will class part of the payments as party donations. This could lead to all sorts of complications. News International, owner of the Times and the Sun, and a quoted stock exchange company, needs approval from shareholders to make donations. Foreign journalists could also be hit. Under the new strict rules party donations are banned from foreigners, although those from European Union companies will be exempt. A ruling from the commission that part of the charge is a donation might force the parties to cut their charges.
